io.atomix.copycat.client

Interface Command<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Operation<T>, Serializable

    public interface Command<T>
extends Operation<T>
    Base interface for operations that modify system state.

    Commands are submitted by clients to a Raft server and used to modify Raft cluster-wide state. When a command is submitted to the cluster, if the command is received by a follower, the Raft protocol dictates that it must be forwarded to the cluster leader. Once the leader receives a command, it logs and replicates the command to a majority of the cluster before applying it to its state machine and responding with the result.

    Consistency levels

    Commands are allow both to modify system state and to trigger events published to client sessions. Whereas Query consistency levels dictate when and how queries can be executed on follower nodes, command consistency levels largely relate to how events triggered by commands are handled. When a command is applied to a server state machine, the consistency level of the command being executed dictates the requirements for handling the event. For instance, in a fictitious lock state machine, one command might be the UnlockCommand. The unlock command would set the state machine state to unlocked and perhaps send a message to any lock waiters notifying them that the lock is available. In this case, linearizable consistency can be used to ensure that lock holders are notified before the unlock operation completes.

    Persistence levels

    Determinism is the number one rule of state machines!

    When commands are submitted to the Raft cluster, they're written to a commit log on disk or in memory (based on the storage configuration) and replicated to a majority of the cluster. As disk usage grows over time, servers compact their logs to remove commands that no longer contribute to the state machine's state. In order to ensure state machines remain deterministic, commands must provide persistence levels to aid servers in deciding when it's safe to remove a command from the log. The persistence level allows state machines to safely handle the complexities of removing state from state machines while ensuring state machines remain deterministic, particularly in the event of a failure and replay of the commit log. See the Command.PersistenceLevel documentation for more info.

    Serialization

    Commands must be serializable both by the client and by all servers in the cluster. By default, all operations use Java serialization. However, default serialization in slow because it requires the full class name and does not allocate memory efficiently. For this reason, it's recommended that commands implement CatalystSerializable or register a custom TypeSerializer for better performance. Serializable types can be registered in a META-INF/services/io.atomix.catalyst.serializer.CatalystSerializable service loader file or on the associated client/server Serializer instance.

    Author:
    Jordan Halterman
    See Also:
    Command.ConsistencyLevel, Command.PersistenceLevel

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      default Command.ConsistencyLevel consistency()
      Returns the command consistency level.
      default Command.PersistenceLevel persistence()
      Returns the command persistence level.

    • Method Detail

      • consistency

        default Command.ConsistencyLevel consistency()
        Returns the command consistency level.

        The consistency will dictate the order with which commands are submitted to the Raft cluster. Ultimately, all commands are linearized by Raft. But commands submitted concurrently by a single client may be received by the cluster out of order. The consistency level allows users to specify how out-of-order commands should be handled. Consult the Command.ConsistencyLevel documentation for more information.

        By default, this method enforces strong consistency with the Command.ConsistencyLevel.LINEARIZABLE consistency level.

        Returns:
        The command consistency level.
        See Also:
        Command.ConsistencyLevel

      • persistence

        default Command.PersistenceLevel persistence()
        Returns the command persistence level.

        The persistence level will dictate how long the command is persisted in the Raft log before it can be cleaned.

        Returns:
        The command persistence level.
        See Also:
        Command.PersistenceLevel
